description.narrative: The project will contribute to strengthen mechanisms for civil society, improve service delivery and upholding human rights. It should support a more enabling legal, social and policy environment, and aim for more accessible, affordable, and quality services tailored to the needs of PUD in Indonesia. Several outputs expected to achieve from the project are: - A training module developed and available for training; - IEC material developed, printed and distributed; - Numbers of peer outreach worker and peer educator trained; - HIV/HCV prevention and its material are included in the outreach package; - Numbers of local stakeholders attending public discussion or workshop; - Increasing of local government commitment to support HIV/HCV prevention, testing, diagnosis and treatment; - HCV DAA drugs is covered under national health insurance scheme; - HCV DAA drugs are available and accessible for key affected population

This activity will focus on PWUD. It is only when communities are experts on HIV, TB and Hepatitis C treatment that they can confidently engage at national, regional and global level. Investment in this area is key, not only for communities to better advocate for their health care (and therefore upholding human rights), but also so that communities can be meaningfully engaged in service provision.

To increase the availability of holistic HIV/HCV response (from prevention, testing, diagnose and treatment) through meaningful involvement of people who use drugs in Indonesia. Some of the activities include developing a training module of HIV/HCV prevention, testing, diagnose and treatment for PUD and establishing partnership with government in an effort to integrate the issue of hepatitis C with HIV, especially in Harm Reduction program.
Disbursement to implement work on HIV and HCV in Indonesia.

Trained service providers is measured through 2 indicators. The first measures the number of service providers trained. Service providers provide social services, including psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, or health NGO or public sector services. The counselling part of VCT services is excluded. They are individuals within local partner organisations within BtG that provide services, as well as from indirect service providers that receive training from BtG local partners for instance other NGO-run clinics, private clinics, state-run services, etc. The second measures the number of legal service providers trained including paralegal services
